unnormalised: The coaching industry in India, especially around competitive exams, is something else, yaar! It’s like a pressure cooker on high heat, whistling louder than a Bollywood item number at 2 AM. Every parent dreams of their child acing the IIT-JEE or NEET, and coaching centres promise to turn that dream into reality…for a hefty fee, of course! They claim a success rate of 99.99%, which probably includes the guy who accidentally walked into the exam hall and signed the attendance sheet.

It's like a pressure cooker on high heat, whistling louder than a Bollywood item number at two A-M. Every parent dreams of their child acing the I-I-T-J-E-E or N-E-E-T, and coaching centers promise to turn that dream into reality…for a hefty fee, of course! They claim a success rate of ninety nine point ninety nine percent, which probably includes the guy who accidentally walked into the exam hall and signed the attendance sheet.

unnormalised: You’ve got students cramming 18 hrs a day, surviving on Maggi and sheer willpower. Forget about social life; their idea of fun is solving a particularly tricky differential equation. The coaching centre becomes their world – a world of mock tests, doubt-clearing sessions, and constant comparisons with Sharma ji ka beta, who, apparently, scored 360/360 in the last practice exam. And don’t even get me started on the names - “Brilliant Brains Academy”, "Quantum Leap Institute”, “Newton’s Nirvana"...as if just by naming themselves that, they’ll magically transfer genius into the students.

unnormalised: The teachers? They're a mix of geniuses and drill sergeants. Some are genuinely passionate, explaining concepts with the patience of a saint. Others are there just to collect a paycheck, rattling off formulas faster than a Rajdhani Express, leaving students wondering if they just witnessed a physics lecture or a speed-reading competition. Remember that one teacher who always said, "This is very important, you MUST know this!". Everything was very important, according to him.

unnormalised: And let's not forget the "study material." Mountains of books thicker than a telephone directory, each page crammed with enough information to make your head explode. It's like they're preparing you for the exam and simultaneously testing your spine's ability to bear the weight. I swear, some of those textbooks could double as doorstops. Plus, the constant barrage of motivational talks – “You are the future of India!”, “Believe in yourself!”, “Don’t give up!”. It’s all very inspiring until you realize you're still stuck on the same problem you were working on three hours ago.
